data.description: Create a Pygame based implementation that includes five classic arcade games (e.g., Snake, Pong, Breakout, Space Invaders, Tetris) and a loading screen allowing the user to select and play any game. Each game should be functional, have basic controls, and be integrated into a main menu. Provide code files for the games and the selection menu. Use a modular structure. No external assets required beyond simple shapes/colors. Ensure the code runs with Python 3.10+ and pygame. Add a README with instructions.

data.description: Define the directory layout, module organization, and shared utilities for the Pygame arcade project. data.description: Create a loading screen with a list of available games and allow the user to select a game to play. Implement navigation using keyboard (up/down arrows, Enter). Use Pygame to display the menu, handle input, and launch the selected game's main function. Ensure the loading screen returns to menu after a game ends. Provide smooth transitions. Keep assets minimal (simple shapes and text).

The game ends when the snake collides with itself or the screen border. Use arrow keys for movement. Display score. Provide a restart option after game over. Keep graphics simple (rectangles).

Use up/down arrow keys for player paddle. AI paddle moves automatically. Score displayed. Game ends when a player reaches a score limit. Simple rectangle graphics. Provide restart after game over.

data.description: Implement the classic Breakout/Arkanoid game in Pygame. Player controls a paddle at the bottom to bounce a ball that breaks bricks at the top. Use left/right arrow keys. Bricks disappear when hit. Ball bounces off walls and paddle. Game ends when ball falls below paddle or all bricks are cleared. Simple rectangle graphics for bricks, paddle, ball. Display score. Provide restart after game over.

Aliens arranged in rows move horizontally and descend slowly. Bullets destroy aliens. Game ends when an alien reaches the bottom or the player loses all lives. Use simple rectangle graphics for ship, aliens, bullets. Provide score and restart after game over.

data.description: Implement the classic Tetris game in Pygame. Randomly falling tetrominoes (I, O, T, S, Z, J, L) descend on a grid. Player can move left/right, rotate, and accelerate descent. Create a config.py that stores SCREEN_WIDTH, SCREEN_HEIGHT, colors, FPS defaults, and key bindings. Update imports throughout the project to use config constants. This centralises tuning and makes future configuration changes easier.

Acceptance Criteria:
- A `config.py` file exists at the repository root defining constants:
  - `SCREEN_WIDTH` (int)
  - `SCREEN_HEIGHT` (int)
  - `FPS` (int)
  - `COLORS` dictionary with keys: `WHITE`, `BLACK`, `RED`, `GREEN`, `BLUE`, and any other colors used in the code, mapping to RGB tuples.
  - Key binding constants: `KEY_QUIT`, `KEY_PAUSE`, `KEY_RESTART`, `KEY_UP`, `KEY_DOWN`, `KEY_LEFT`, `KEY_RIGHT`.
- All references to these constants in the codebase (including `utils.py` and game modules) are replaced with imports from `config.py`.
- The `Engine` class uses `config.FPS` for its default frame rate and `config.SCREEN_WIDTH`/`config.SCREEN_HEIGHT` for screen dimensions.
- Running the project after changes works without errors and visual behavior matches previous defaults.
- Existing test suite passes, and new tests verify that `config` constants have the expected values and that modules import them correctly.
data.title: Move constants to config module

data.description:
When a game ends, the player's score is saved to a JSON file specific to the game (e.g., highscore_snake.json). The file stores an array of score entries with a timestamp. On the Game‑Over screen the top 5 scores are loaded from this file and displayed sorted descending.

Acceptance Criteria:
1. A JSON file named `highscore_<game>.json` is created/updated on game over with the player's score and timestamp.
2. If the file does not exist, it is created automatically.
3. The Game‑Over screen reads the file and displays the top 5 scores, sorted from highest to lowest.
4. The displayed scores show the numeric score and the date/time of each entry.
5. Scores persist across multiple runs of the same game.
6. Separate JSON files are used for each game; scores from one game do not affect another.
7. No unhandled exceptions occur if the file is missing or malformed; the system falls back to an empty score list.
8. Unit tests cover writing scores, reading and sorting scores, and handling missing files.,description:Update description with proper placeholder}
data.title: Add high‑score persistence per game

data.description:
Add sound effects, background music, and a mute toggle for all arcade games, persisting mute state in `settings.json`.

## Problem statement
The arcade suite currently has no audio feedback; players cannot hear sound effects for game events or background music, and there is no way to mute audio. This work item adds sound effects, background music, and a mute toggle for all games.

## Users
- Players of the classic arcade games (Snake, Pong, Breakout, Space Invaders, Tetris, etc.)
- Developers and maintainers who need a simple, configurable audio system.

## Success criteria
- Sound effects play for key events in each game (e.g., snake food beep, Pong bounce, Tetris line clear, etc.)
- A looping background music track plays during gameplay for each game.
- Pressing **M** toggles the mute flag on/off both in the main menu and during gameplay.
- The mute state is persisted in `settings.json` and restored on game launch.
- All required WAV files must be placed under `assets/sounds/`. If a suitable file is missing, copy the `placeholder.wav` into `assets/sounds/` and rename it to a descriptive name (e.g., `snake_beep.wav`). A child work item must be created (using `wl create`) referencing this name, making it easier for designers to add the proper sound.

## Constraints
- Use `pygame.mixer` for audio playback.
- Assets must live in `assets/sounds/` relative to the repository root.
- No new third‑party dependencies beyond `pygame`.
- The mute flag must be stored in `settings.json` (created if missing) and loaded at startup.
- The implementation must not break existing game logic or the test suite.

## Existing state
- No audio handling code exists in the repository.
- `config.py` defines screen dimensions, colours, and key bindings but no mute flag.
- No `settings.json` file is present.

## Desired change
- Add a global mute flag (`MUTE`) to `config.py` with a default of `False`.
- Extend the engine or game base to initialise `pygame.mixer` and load the required sound assets.
- Add per‑game sound effect calls at appropriate events.
- Add background music playback that respects the mute flag.
- Implement a UI toggle: pressing **M** flips the mute flag, updates `settings.json`, and shows the current mute state on screen.
- Create the `assets/sounds/` directory and add placeholder WAV files as needed.

## Suggested next step
- Implement the audio system as described, ensuring all games load their specific sound effects and background music, add the mute toggle, persist settings, and create any required placeholder sound child work items.

## Related work
- **User Experience Enhancements** (G1-0ML5DP1QU0NORR15) – epic that includes “sound & music”.
- **Add settings screen** (G1-0ML5DR43J1U40BIQ) – previously defined a settings screen with volume control (deleted, but still relevant for persisting mute state).

## Risks & assumptions
- **Risk:** Missing sound files could cause runtime errors; fallback to `placeholder.wav` ensures the game still runs.
- **Assumption:** `pygame.mixer` works on all target platforms (desktop environments where the arcade runs).
- **Risk:** Audio initialization may slightly increase startup time.
- **Assumption:** The `settings.json` file is writable and will be loaded early in the application.
- **Risk:** Inconsistent mute state across different game loops; using a single global mute flag mitigates this.
data.title: Add sound and music with mute toggle

data.description:
Problem statement:
Headline summary: Add adjustable difficulty scaling across all games via a common settings screen, persisting per‑game difficulty in `settings.json`.
Add adjustable difficulty scaling to the arcade suite, exposing Easy, Medium, and Hard settings that affect gameplay parameters such as game speed, enemy AI, and spawn rates for each game.

Users:
- Players who want to choose a suitable challenge level.
- Developers who need a configurable difficulty for testing and balancing.

Success criteria:
- A common settings screen allows selection of Easy, Medium, Hard for each game.
- Selected difficulty is persisted per game in `settings.json` and loaded on launch.
- Each game adjusts at least one core parameter based on difficulty (e.g., speed multiplier, AI aggressiveness, spawn rate).
- No regression in existing gameplay; all unit and integration tests pass.
- Documentation updates reflect the new difficulty options.

Constraints:
- Use the existing `config` module and settings persistence mechanism.
- UI must reuse the common settings screen framework.
- Store difficulty keys in lowercase (e.g., `snake_difficulty`).
- Maintain backward compatibility for existing users (default to Medium if no setting).

Risks & assumptions:
- **Risk**: Incorrect difficulty multipliers could unbalance gameplay, leading to frustration or triviality.
- **Risk**: Modifying the settings UI may introduce regressions in existing UI features (fullscreen toggle, volume control, key bindings, theme).
- **Risk**: Persistence failures (e.g., corrupted `settings.json`) could prevent loading difficulty settings; fallback to Medium is required.
- **Assumption**: The `settings.json` file is writable in the user's environment.
- **Assumption**: Existing games can accept speed/AI adjustments without extensive refactoring.
- **Assumption**: Players will access the settings screen via the **S** key as defined.
- **Assumption**: Default difficulty for new installations is Medium.

Existing state:
- No difficulty setting exists; only mute flag is persisted.
- A deleted work item `Add settings screen` (G1-0ML5DR43J1U40BIQ) defined a settings menu reachable from the main menu (key **S**) with options to toggle fullscreen, adjust sound volume, select key bindings, choose difficulty level, and switch between light/dark theme. The settings were intended to be persisted in a small JSON file (`settings.json`), but the UI was never implemented.
- The `Gameplay Polish` epic groups difficulty scaling with other polish tasks.

Desired change:
- Extend `config` with a `DIFFICULTY` enum and default value.
- Implement a common settings UI component for selecting difficulty per game (accessible via key **S** from the main menu).
- Modify each game's update loop to apply difficulty multipliers.
- Persist selections in `settings.json`.

Related work:
- Add settings screen (G1-0ML5DR43J1U40BIQ) – defines a settings menu including difficulty.
- Gameplay Polish (G1-0ML5DP5XG1ILV4HA) – parent epic for polish tasks.
- Child work items created for each game:
  - Add difficulty scaling to Snake (G1-0MLAK2OCV0AUDRYV)
  - Add difficulty scaling to Pong (G1-0MLAK2UMP0VL280M)
  - Add difficulty scaling to Breakout (G1-0MLAK31DG0I2SHTN)
  - Add difficulty scaling to Space Invaders (G1-0MLAK38JO0ZZCLF8)
  - Add difficulty scaling to Tetris (G1-0MLAK3FJG0AOL3DB)
data.title: Add adjustable difficulty scaling

data.description:
Player cannot fire projectiles and enemies do not fire back, breaking core gameplay. Fix player shooting and enemy shooting.

Acceptance Criteria:
1. Pressing SPACE spawns a player bullet at the player's ship.
2. Player bullets move upward at BULLET_SPEED and are removed when leaving the screen.
3. Player bullets destroy aliens on collision, removing the bullet and alien, and increase score.
4. Enemies fire bullets downward from a random alien at regular intervals (approx. every 2 seconds).
5. Enemy bullets move downward at BULLET_SPEED and are removed when leaving the screen.
6. Enemy bullets colliding with the player end the game (game_over=True).
7. Player bullets are drawn in YELLOW, enemy bullets in RED.
8. Player shooting has a cooldown of 0.75 seconds between bullets.
9. Automated tests verify shooting, bullet movement, cooldown behavior, and collision behavior.
,json:true}
data.title: Space Invaders cannot shoot; enemies do not shoot back

data.description:
When the game window is closed, the frame remains and the process must be killed manually. Implement proper shutdown handling to exit cleanly.

Acceptance Criteria:
1. Closing the window (pygame.QUIT) causes the Engine loop to exit, the running flag becomes False, and pygame quits cleanly (no lingering window or process). After Engine.run() returns, pygame.get_init() should be False.
2. The code registers an atexit cleanup that calls pygame.quit() (import atexit, define cleanup(), atexit.register(cleanup)). This should be present in the main entry point or core engine module.
3. Automated test validates that after simulating a QUIT event, Engine.run() returns and pygame.get_init() is False.
data.title: Window close does not terminate process

data.description:
Play a brick‑hit sound on each brick destruction and a bounce sound on paddle hits.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Brick‑hit sound plays for every brick removed.
- Paddle‑bounce sound plays on each paddle collision.
- Both respect the mute flag.
- Unit tests verify the correct calls.
data.title: Breakout sound integration

data.description:
Play a shoot sound when the player fires, an alien‑hit sound on enemy destruction, an enemy‑shoot sound when enemies fire, a cover‑impact sound when enemy bullets hit shelters, a player‑hit sound when the player is hit, and a game‑over sound when the game ends.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Shoot sound plays on every player shot.
- Alien‑hit sound plays for each enemy destroyed.
- Enemy‑shoot sound plays for each enemy bullet fired.
- Cover‑impact sound plays when an enemy bullet hits a shelter block.
- Player‑hit sound plays when an enemy bullet hits the player.
- Game‑over sound plays when the game ends (player loses).
- All sounds respect the mute flag.
- Unit tests verify the correct calls.,
data.title: Space Invaders sound integration

data.description:
Play a line‑clear sound when a line is removed and a rotate sound on piece rotation.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Line‑clear sound plays once per cleared line.
- Rotate sound plays on each rotation action.
- Both respect the mute flag.
- Unit tests verify the correct calls.
data.title: Tetris sound integration

data.description:
Provide a placeholder.wav in assets/sounds/. When a required sound file is missing, copy placeholder.wav, rename it descriptively, and automatically create a child work item referencing the missing asset.

## Acceptance Criteria
- placeholder.wav exists in the repository.
- ensure_sound(name) checks for the file, copies/renames placeholder if absent.
- A child work item is generated via wl create for each missing sound asset, referencing the game and sound name.
- No runtime errors when assets are missing; the placeholder allows the game to run.
data.title: Asset placeholder handling

data.description:
Summary
Play a random music file when the main menu is visible and when a game session starts.

User stories
- As a player I want background music on the menu so the app feels lively.
- As a player I want music to start when a game begins so the experience is immersive.

Expected behaviour / Acceptance criteria
1) When the menu screen becomes visible (any entry to the menu), the app selects one music file at random from the project's music assets and begins playback.
2) When a game is started from the menu, the app either: a) continue playing the current track, or b) select and play another random track (pick one consistent behaviour and document it) — the implementation should default to selecting a new random track on game start unless configured otherwise.
3) Only one music track may be playing at any time. Starting a new track stops the previous track cleanly.
4) Music playback respects global audio settings (mute, volume) and any platform-specific audio focus rules.
5) Music selection must exclude non-music assets (SFX) and only pick from the designated music folder/pattern.
6) Provide a small unit/integration test (or a deterministic dev hook) to verify that the random selection and start/stop behavior trigger when menu/game events occur.

Suggested implementation notes
- Locate the project's music assets (e.g. assets/music, public/music, or similar). If there is an existing audio manager/service, extend it with a `playRandomMusic(context)` helper.
- Hook into the lifecycle/events for: `menuVisible` and `gameStarted` (or equivalent). On menuVisible -> call playRandomMusic(menuContext). On gameStarted -> call playRandomMusic(gameContext) or allow continuing current track (document choice).
- Ensure selection uses a true random pick with a small guard to avoid immediate repeats if desired (optional).
- Add configuration to toggle the feature (enable/disable) and to select behavior on game start (continue vs new track).
- Files likely touched: audio manager/service, menu UI code, game start handler, asset manifest. Add tests that simulate menu visible and game start events.

Notes
- discovered-from:G1-0ML5DP1QU0NORR15

data.description:
Summary: The Game Over screen is difficult to read because the active game screen remains fully visible behind it. We should fade/dim the game canvas when the Game Over overlay is visible to improve text contrast and readability.

User story: As a player who just lost, I want the Game Over text to be clearly readable over the current game view so I can see my score and options without background distraction.

Expected behavior:
- When the Game Over screen is shown, the game rendering behind it must be dimmed with a semi-opaque overlay (e.g. black at 40%-70% opacity) or an animated fade-in dimming effect.
- When the Game Over screen is dismissed (restart/return to menu), the dimming overlay is removed or fades out.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Play the game until the Game Over screen appears.
2. Observe that the game scene behind the Game Over overlay remains fully visible and makes the Game Over text hard to read.

Suggested implementation approach:
- Add a semi-opaque full-screen overlay element that becomes visible when the Game Over state is active and fades in/out via CSS or canvas drawing.
- Prefer adding the overlay in the GameOver component or the top-level UI layer so it covers the game canvas without altering game rendering logic.
- Use configurable opacity and transition durations; add tests or manual QA steps to verify contrast.

Acceptance criteria:
- The Game Over overlay triggers a dimming overlay behind the Game Over UI when visible.
- The overlay fades in within ~250-500ms and fades out when dismissed.
- The Game Over text is visually readable (WCAG AA contrast recommended) with the overlay applied.
- No functional regressions in gameplay or UI layering.

Notes:
- Parent work item: G1-0ML5DP1QU0NORR15
- Priority: medium
- Issue-type: bug
data.title: Fade background when Game Over visible

data.description:
Summary: Ensure audio asset filenames used by games are consistently prefixed with the game name (e.g. space_invaders_player_shoot).

User story: As a developer and release engineer, I want all game audio files to include the game slug as a prefix so that assets are uniquely identifiable, avoid collisions across games, and make automated asset packaging and lookup reliable.

Expected behaviour: New and existing audio files referenced by games should follow the pattern: <game_slug>_<asset_path_or_name> (lowercase, snake_case). Build/packaging scripts and runtime loaders should reference the updated names or support backward-compatible mapping.

Acceptance criteria:
- All audio filenames used in game projects are prefixed with the game's slug (e.g. space_invaders_player_shoot).
- CI or a linting script can validate audio filenames and fail the build if naming is incorrect.
- A migration plan or mapping file exists for any renamed assets so existing saved data or references do not break.

Suggested implementation steps:
1. Add a lint rule or CI check to validate audio filenames in each game repo.
2. Update game asset manifests/loaders to expect or map prefixed names.
3. Create a small migration utility or mapping file for renamed assets.
4. Run an audit of current audio assets and create PRs to rename and update references where needed.

Related tags: audio,naming,ci
data.title: Prefix audio filenames with game name

data.description: Implement difficulty levels (Easy/Medium/Hard) for Snake. Easy uses base speed (SNAKE_SPEED=10). Medium increases speed by 1.5x. Hard increases speed by 2x. Store selected difficulty in settings.json under key "snake_difficulty" and apply on game start.
data.title: Add difficulty scaling to Snake

data.description: Implement difficulty levels for Pong. Easy: default ball speed (BALL_SPEED_X/Y=4) and paddle speed (PADDLE_SPEED=5). Medium: increase ball speed by 1.5x and paddle speed by 1.2x. Hard: increase ball speed by 2x and paddle speed by 1.5x, and improve AI reaction time. Store difficulty under "pong_difficulty" in settings.json and apply on game start.
data.title: Add difficulty scaling to Pong

data.description: Implement difficulty levels for Breakout. Easy: default BALL_SPEED=5 and PADDLE_SPEED=6. Medium: increase ball speed by 1.5x and paddle speed by 1.2x, and optionally add extra bricks. Hard: increase ball speed by 2x and paddle speed by 1.5x, and increase brick durability (require multiple hits). Store difficulty under "breakout_difficulty" in settings.json and apply on game start.
data.title: Add difficulty scaling to Breakout

data.description: Implement difficulty levels for Space Invaders. Easy: default PLAYER_SPEED=5, ENEMY_SPEED=1, BULLET_SPEED=7. Medium: increase ENEMY_SPEED by 1.5x and BULLET_SPEED by 1.2x, and increase spawn rate. Hard: increase ENEMY_SPEED by 2x, BULLET_SPEED by 1.5x, and increase enemy spawn frequency. Store difficulty under "space_invaders_difficulty" in settings.json and apply on game start.
data.title: Add difficulty scaling to Space Invaders

data.description: Implement difficulty levels for Tetris. Easy: default FALL_SPEED=500 ms per step. Medium: increase fall speed by 1.5x (≈333 ms). Hard: increase fall speed by 2x (≈250 ms) and increase level-up speed (reduce FALL_SPEED decrement). Store difficulty under "tetris_difficulty" in settings.json and apply on game start.
data.title: Add difficulty scaling to Tetris

data.comment:
**Acceptance Criteria**
- pyproject.toml with correct metadata (name, version, description, readme, license MIT, author, python >=3.10)
- dependencies include pygame>=2.0
- build-system uses setuptools>=61.0 and wheel
- console script entry point classic-arcade = main:main
- MANIFEST.in includes README.md and LICENSE
- LICENSE file with MIT text present
- pip install . works and installs classic-arcade script
- running classic-arcade prints 'Starting Arcade Suite'
- all existing pytest tests pass

data.comment: Fixed: M now toggles music volume when mixer is initialised; Engine initialises audio at startup (audio.init), MenuState handles M key as well, and mute status text was shifted right to avoid overlapping the yellow indicator. Verified via tests. Commit: 32601dd.

Updated tests to prefer introspection over pixel sampling. Commit: cb10d0c.

data.comment: Added fade behavior: mute fades out over 0.5s; unmute attempts a 0.5s fade-in by starting playback with fade_ms when supported. Updated tests to remove direct pixel sampling where possible. Commit: 6d3b218.
